thread.title: After a day on the lam and 3 tranquilizer darts, Yellow Nose the wayward oryx back home
thread.title_full: After a day on the lam and 3 tranquilizer darts, Yellow Nose the wayward oryx back home | OregonLive.com

author: Steve Mayes | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: After a day on the lam and 3 tranquilizer darts, Yellow Nose the wayward oryx back home
text:
It took three tranquilizer darts Sunday morning to subdue Yellow Nose, a wayward oryx who escaped his enclosure and became the talk of the town after meandering into Forest Park.
The exotic animal, a scimitar-horned antelope native to Africa, is a member of an 11-oryx herd owned by Reed Gleason on a large fenced pasture on Northwest Skyline Boulevard.
Until Saturday, when Yellow Nose left home through a gate inadvertently left open, most Portlanders probably didn't know an oryx from and an onyx. But within a day, hundreds of people got an up-close look at the former as Yellow Nose wandered along Northwest Leif Erickson Drive, a gated road that runs through the park.
Yellow Nose stopped for the night about a mile up Leif Erickson, just south of Northwest Germantown Road.
"He'd been running from people until he couldn't run anymore," Gleason said.
The exhausted animal lay beside heavily traveled Leif Erickson, about three miles from his home. Yellow Nose became an unexpected roadside attraction for a steady stream of hikers and bikers.
Despite his long curving horns and hefty size, Yellow Nose posed no immediate danger to passersby if he isn't disturbed, Gleason said.
"(Oryx) are not tame, but they're not threatening," Gleason said Sunday after he and two veterinarians captured the beast about noon.
Gleason is known for his devotion to oryx. He has posted adorable videos to YouTube, including this one:
On Saturday, Gleason and Tony Adams, who helps care for the oryx herd, spent the night in the woods until 5 a.m. monitoring Yellow Nose's whereabouts. They parked a trailer on the road near the animal and tried to entice Yellow Nose inside with grain.
Yellow Nose wasn't buying.
The oryx moved around a little but didn't travel far, Gleason said. "He'd go up the road a ways. Maybe he was trying to go home."
Plan B called for drugging the animal. That required an expert.
"I didn't think we'd find anybody to come out on a Sunday," Gleason said.
Gleason contacted a veterinary clinic in Woodburn that once cared for the oryx. Blake Miller, who works at the clinic, and Brian Dietrich, who used to work there, responded.
As the veterinarians prepared the tranquilizer dose and readied the rifle, a runner stopped to ask what was happening.
"Road maintenance," deadpanned one of the vets to the disbelieving runner.
Dietrich, moving with a hunter's stealth, quietly stepped through the underbrush to get a clear shot. A full-grown oryx weights more than 300 pounds and provides an ample target.
Yellow Nose, hit twice, didn't go down.
He got up and walked about 150 yards up the road, the veterinarians close on his heels.
Dietrich reloaded. After waving off a couple of cyclists and a woman walking her dog, he fired one more dart. Yellow Nose again seemed unaffected and took a few steps off the road.
Then he wobbled and fell. The vets secured the oryx and loaded Yellow Nose into a trailer for the short ride home.
Back in Gleason's fenced pasture, the vets administered a drug to counteract the tranquilizer's narcotic effect. Yellow Nose remained woozy but slowly revived, mooing and chewing his cud.
Gleason, a semi-retired electrical engineer, was greatly relieved.
"That was a long night, man, I'm sure glad it's over," Gleason said as he walked in his front door. "That was quite an adventure for me."
And of course, this being Portland, naturally this happened:

-- Betsy Hammond and Elliot Njus of The Oregonian/OregonLive staff contributed to this report.
-- Steve Mayes
